comment.author: 84511729@N00
comment._content: Looks like it was taken about here: maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=Merchants+Quay,+Newry&hl=en&...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/skink74] Spot on - we can just see the street sign for Edward Street at extreme right. Thank you!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Interesting to see all the hoists on the warehouses, like you still see in the Netherlands and the north of Germany today.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: You've lots of business names. They should help date it once the experts get here.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Godfrey Bridge: Type: Swing, Built: c.1865, Construction: iron, wood, Power: Manual, Use: Road www.movablebridges.org.uk/BridgePage.asp?BridgeNumber=1087

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The gateway with the flagpole appears to be the customs house, according to the OSNI map.

comment.author: 37107521@N00
comment._content: in addition to context and history .... it is an amazingly sharp, detailed (and well preseved!) and well composed photo

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: how would ships of this size been towed up the canal to this point?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] Using "sweeps" long oars to row up, poles to pole their way in shallow water and horses where there was a tow path beside the canal.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: What a beaut of an image!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: I can find James Greer (Coal and seed merchant) and Robert Brown (Pork curers and provisions) in the 1900 Street Directory. I cannot find Andrew Todd.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Greer and Brown are there in 1895 too. streetdirectories.proni.gov.uk/app/WebObjects/StreetDirec...

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Greer and Brown are there in 1892.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Does the Andrew Todd building mention Dublin or am I imagining it?

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Thanks, I had considered the horse but there is very little room outside the bollards and the poles would have to have been very long and heavy with so much freeboard. Is there any possibility that these ships would have been towed by large multi-maned row boats?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content:
In  the 1870 directory Greer and Brown are there and so is a Louis Martin  - spirit dealer and grocer - not sure if this is the right Martin but it is the only one in Merchant Quay. Again as in 1900 the only Todds mentioned is a John Todd in Sugar Island. 

Sorry I am not being much help here!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Yes - I see Dublin too. I suppose a hunt for that firm in Dublin might produce the years of the business?

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: I'd say the boom accross the canal is an improvised footbridge for dockers or sailors to cross the canal. Looking at the angle and the lenght it is probably long enough to span the canal at 90degrees when the ship leaves.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] Whatever it is, it wasn't a feature worthy of a place on the map in 1861.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] yeah, but it is small things like this that give insight  and make sense of everyday life at that time.

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: Another wonderful old picture NLI, well done, I love it!  (And I'm not even Irish)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] You are quite right, towing a ship of that size would require a large team of horses and plenty of room for manoevre.  The possibility of a launch or launchs with rowing and towing is there though it would have been a very hard pull for the poor oarsmen.  How deep were those canals?  I doubt the draft of the ships was that great, 6 to 10 feet perhaps?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] I found a link to google books where a will by a William Todd mentioned that he had rented his Mills in Jones's Road, Dublin to his son, there was a court case against Andrew for the rent he owed his father but he got off the hook.  And he also appears in "The Commercial Directory" as Andrew Todd, Steam Flour Millers, Jones Road, Dublin.  The court case was in 1879 though the mill had been in the family for much longer and 1851 is mentioned as well.

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: What a wonderful image. Love that reflection. Incredible for such an old photo.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] I meant more that the surveyors were dullards (or at least unhelpful for dating things) than that the boom isn't interesting.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] That sounds like the right Todd! But we still can't narrow the date down.

comment.author: 37424391@N07
comment._content: Respect,.!!!!

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] The draft would have been a minimum 6 feet with plenty ballast to counter the rig and that is why I discount polling. The canals must have been failrly deep in those times.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I get that. I did not mean to dis you. Apologies. Keep up the good work.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So, we're definitely after c. 1865 (swing bridge, thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] ) and 1870 is a possibility based on the merchants (thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] )...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: How big is the original glass negative? Ahh... a stereo pair, so probably not one of the big 8x10 or larger formats. Still, those old glass negatives produce wonderfully clear imagery.

comment.author: 38088948@N05
comment._content: brilliant!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/seaveyfamily] The original "pair" measures 3¼ x 6¾", but as you say, the glass negatives are what give the clarity...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 12814971@N00
comment._content: Given the size of the ON this is a great image. The really big glass plate cameras produce absolutely gorgeous stuff. Of course they weren't what you could call portable, or fast, but for nice still scenes, oh my!
